page.title: 20Historic Houses, Wray area
page.content: {Smeer Hall}(in earlier times Smere Hawe and Haugh) is well-hidden from the Roeburndale roads. The land is not good for farming but coal was once mined at Smeer Hall pits. The house dates from the seventeenth century and some original latticed windows remain. There is a courtroom where prisoners were tried by a travelling judge and a cellar where prisoners were kept before going to Outhwaite prison. At{Outhwaite,}there are about seven houses now used for storage and for animals, and one still used as a farmhouse. There is the old prison, stone stocks and a whipping post. The grander{Cragg Hall}was built by the Bateson family in the seventeenth century and enlarged in Georgian and Victorian times. The gloomy pond in the grounds may be an old quarry.
